timeline.bodyText: (applies to the entire Argument hierarchy): is there a reason why we use a programmatic serialization to JSON instead of a declarative one (via annotations)?
timeline.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText: yes, the graphql queries are mostly managed a as json definition, and this queries are built dynamically. The argument container e.g. permits arguments of different nature, and everything is finally built up since the arguments are transformable to json nodes.
replies.author: wmedvede

timeline.bodyText: Let's not print stacktraces to output; they will just bloat the console log. If there is a problem in test setup, we should fail fast with an exception and not wait for tests that rely on certain preconditions to fail.
timeline.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText:
Maybe do the new URL(serviceUrl()); here do deal with already sanitized input later?
See https://github.com/kiegroup/kogito-apps/pull/562/files#diff-b360b2e8ac16f3751a4d940473e56ed427025347cc34972205c9710946de65bbR51.
timeline.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText: Is there a plan for such an implementation? Truly, it would be much better to rely on such a full-fledged implementation than doing it ourselves just for the Task Assigning.
timeline.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText: There are voices that such thing will exist at some point, but nobody knows when. So, to summarize, when such implementation exists (if exists) my code is prepared to integrate it. Until it not exists, I'll go with this implementation.
replies.author: wmedvede

timeline.bodyText: The fact that the second parameter (provided by the method source) is not used feels strange. It happens because the method source is used by another test method, defined in the parent class.
